ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned new Spanish tenses, improved my speaking skills, and heard lots of great, fun songs from Juliana, la reina.
I improved my Spanish writing, listening, reading, and speaking skills. I especially developed my Spanish presentation skills through numerous presentations we had throughout the semester.
I improved my ability to speak Spanish, as well as understand verbal and written components of the language. I learned to communicate using more tenses that just the present and preterite.
I learned basic Spanish grammar, speaking skills, and about Hispanic culture.
How to speak, write, and read at the Spanish II level

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: great class discussions
Weaknesses: most of the final exam was easy, but there were some parts (such as the first section) that would have been helpful if we reviewed some of these grammar rules and with verbs

This course was excellent overall given the circumstances. Of course, an in-person format would be a lot better for this course given that it is a language course. Regardless, I feel like I learned a lot from this course.

The strengths of this course is that it is very organized, with small classes that really allow for individual attention. Also, the coursework is engaging and definitely improves your understanding of the language.

This course felt like it had many pointless assignments every night, however, I think that in the long run this enforced listening skills and helped with learning overall. I did wish for more engaging assignments overall, but there was a lot of speaking practice in this class which definitely improved my confidence and ability to hold a conversation.
Very engaging and informative

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was so chill, very engaging. Everyone loved it, and Juliana is the kindest.
The presentations were really engaging even on Zoom and collaborative projects (such as recordings) also worked really well.
The requirement of video camera on and participating verbally in the class definitely improved the learning environment.

Virtual homework assignments were mostly great, though trying to write in a different language on a Canvas exam is not the most fun thing in the world. I definitely liked having a living document of all of my written assignments! We tried having virtual "walks" with classmates to just discuss anything (but in Spanish) to sort of mimic being in person. While I got to talk to a few of my classmates one-on-one, it felt forced because it was graded.
Supersite and Canvas quizzes were helpful review.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learning foreign languages is always important!
Yes, I definitely would. It's a highly engaging, challenging yet fun class. I also got to learn a lot about Hispanic countries and cultures which was fascinating.
Absolutely, the course is a great continuation of L1 Spanish, and you will feel prepared for L3 Spanish.
Yes - great progress in Spanish learning

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
Supersite
